comments.commentBody: What is clear is that JPMorgan is guilty of years of securities fraud involving hundreds of billions of dollars worth of fraudulently-presented, fraudulently-priced junk. Obviously, the people responsible as well as the executives who approved of the practice should spend decades in jail and never be allowed to work in finance again. They knowingly sold fraudulent goods. The lied and profited mightily from those lies. They stole billions of dollars. For justice to prevail, this settlement should be rejected by the court.

They may keep the name, but the character of the neighborhood will be destroyed in a few years. However, change is part of life and one day in the future, it will become again a neighborhood more suited to its name.

Crosstown bus, E, C in the neighborhood, all on 50th. 1 on 50th, N, R 49th one block away. Times Square two blocks away, 42nd St. crosstown bus.

On the southern end, Columbus Circle 3 blocks out of the neighborhood.

It's hardly underserved by public transportation.

The eastern boundary of Hell's Kitchen (between 42nd and 57th) has always been 8th Avenue and it is true that there are subway stops at 50th and 8th and at 42nd and 8th, but it's a very long way from many of the high rises going up west of 10th Avenue (the part of the neighborhood where they are permitted) to the trains. Buses do serve both crosstown and up/down travelers, but it is distances like those in western Hell's Kitchen that have led to the construction of the 2nd Avenue subway on the Upper East Side. Lots more clout up there than in Hell's Kitchen -- and lots more people, too.

The real beauty of living in Hell's kitchen (in addition to the fact that the sun still shines there because of the constantly threatened special zoning district) is that one can walk -- to work in Midtown, to Central Park, to the new Hudson River Park and to all the Theaters and wonders of Midtown Manhattan.

The article makes no mention of public transportation---and that's a big item no matter where you live in the city.Even in the "silk stocking" neighborhoods of the upper east side there is phenomenal transportation.
I am sorry to hear that Americans are so afraid of each other they can't ask anyone for help.
If you're so willing to pay the true cost of health insurance, then do so without the temporary 3 year subsidies.

@QP

You're a lawyer, right? Hard to believe sometimes, but you've so defined yourself and I believe you. So why assume, nay, insist that "Joe-Jen and the NYT editorial board showed no respect whatsoever, nor any deference to, the judicial process that led to Zimmerman's aquittal. And they continue to second guess the decisions of courts in self-defense cases.

All of which cases they now wrongly lump together as hinging on "Stand Your Ground" defenses."

Are you attempting to say that our judicial system is perfect, that no guilty person has ever been acquitted, or that no innocent person has ever been convicted?

The judicial process acquitted George Zimmerman. That acquittal doesn't mean he was innocent -- only that the court found him innocent. Ditto for the court that found O.J. Simpson innocent. Was he in fact innocent? Not necessarily. All we can say in either of these notorious cases (and many others I won't bother to cite) is that the juries concluded the defendants were worthy of acquittal.

How that shows that Joe and Jen or the NYT editorial board "showed no respect whatsoever" for the judicial process seems like quite a leap.

If you have such a low opinion of the Times, why do you bother to read it?

Clairette--

I was a criminal defense attorney for 5 years in Colorado before going into corporate law, oh, about 15 years ago now. (Wow. Time flies.)

I can assure you that our criminal justice system is far from perfect.

Judges, juries, and prosecutors can and do get it wrong.

My point was that if anyone has been prone to rush to judgement, or second guess jury verdicts, it isn't those of us standing up for the rights of gun owners.

But if the system really is so unreliable, why make it EASIER for prosecutors to send people -- who might well be innocent of criminal wrongdoing -- to death row by LOWERING the state's burden of proof in capital cases?

QP

Deb -

We have not seen the forensics yet.

Also, declaring Ted Wafer a murder without a his day in court is morally rong. Innocent until proven guilty beyond a reasonable doubt is still the standard.

Mr. Wafer does not have to prove anything, the DA has to prove, beyond a reasonable doubt, he committed the crime. The law is written that way, especially in these cases, to avoid having a DA with a political agenda (AKA Angela Corry) to get vengeance, not justice.

JWC, how about considering factual information on the Trayvon Martin shooting? I understand it's an emotional issue. A young man is dead, another man's life in shambles, so emotions can run pretty high. It's a tragedy all around, but in an honest discussion you shouldn't gloss over the inconsistencies of your position.

Here is an objective, fact based article on the subject:

http://americanhandgunner.com/lessons-from-the-zimmerman-case/
DJ, you're not exactly the poster boy for reasonable arguments either . . .

Check out the millions spent on compensation for 10 execs at a public hospital. Granted theses salaries are nearly as much as insurance company execs but this is a nonprofit in a very affordable city.
http://www.bizjournals.com/charlotte/news/2013/02/05/carolinas-healthcar...

With regard to Theodora30's comment.

I have pointed this out repeatedly and I will do so again until it sinks in.

Some very fine organisations are nonprofits. But in the realm of the so-called 'eds and meds' (educational institutions, hospitals) it's no better than a for-profit company and often worse in that the profiteers cloak themselves in the special aura of virtue that surrounds a 'nonprofit'.

'Nonprofit' is a form of corporate organisation that simply means the company does not issue stock and pay dividends to stockholders. All it means is that any excess is instead ploughed back into the company. There is no special virtue in it, and it is not synonymous with 'charity'. Everyone who works there, from the haughtiest neurosurgeon to the lowliest janitor, is very much for profit. They tend to overpay their executives and have bloated PR and communications departments, like our local nonprofit hospital, dedicated to producing glossy mailings and fullpage NYT ads telling you how wonderful they are. I can't open the online NYT without being deluged with their ads on every page. I have no doubt the NYT is not providing them that space for free. The hospital's now trying to ram an unpopular multimillion-$ expansion plan through the local planning board. The details show this expansion is not exactly geared toward helping the poor.

We have watched the GOP work every possible glitch to disable the ACA.
No matter the benefits, or what the purpose is, they have continued to publicize every single complaint, and make it look unworkable.

They do not, will not have any suggestions for correcting the errors, they are determined to cancel it, to undo it. Yo have to ask here the same question you should ask of any legislation: who benefits, who profits from it, what is the real purpose of any legislation?

In this case the answer is not hard to find, all you have to do, is look at the profits of the HMOs, the medical insurance companies, and the pay scales of their executives. Then ask, how is it that so much money can be made providing people with health insurance.

To make such profits, you have to charge more than you pay out, and to do that, you have to set limits to what you will pay for, and we have seen the consequences of that. That is the reason congress passed the ACA, but it was sabotaged from the start with faulty legislation. You can lay odds the GOP was well aware of those errors, and just waiting to take advantage of them, with the medical insurance companies giving them all the support they needed.

"Health Insurance CEO Paid $106 Million.
www.creators.com ›
In all, the CEOs of America's 10 largest health insurance companies made $228.1 million in salary and stock options during 2009, according to the liberal "

https://www.google.com/#q=health+insurance+companies+ceo+salaries

Thanks responding "for the record", Jen, but I note that your response fails to confirm whether or not you agree or disagree with the assertion that a woman is best advised not to own a gun for personal protection because "Too many times, their male counterpart or spouse will be able to overpower them and take that gun away.”

I think the theme of your blog -- that woman gun owners are too easily overpowered by men -- was obvious.

But maybe I got it wrong and you agree with me that women are smart enough, competent enough, capable enough, and responsible enough to decide for themselves, based on the totality of their individual circumstances, whether or not owning a gun for personal protection is in their best interest. If you do agree with me on that point, then we've found some common ground.

The president did declare war, he did kill thousands of people in war, he said the war on terror is universal and he can bomb anyone anywhere, he said girls shouldn't be able to get the morning after pill without a parent's consent...yes, absolutely, shame on him.

I appreciate the curiosity about my beliefs. However, my job isn't to opine, but to present. The only time I wrote in the first person was when I eulogized my friend, who died from gun violence. Joe is the one whose opinions people want to read. I am merely carrying out his vision, and I prefer to leave the opinions to him. What I do, and what I feel comfortable doing, is to present current stories that are out there that revolve around the gun debate in America today. We aim to present logical voices for dealing with this problem - a problem that has accelerated in the last 50 years. I think that is beyond dispute.

Thanks for your feedback.

Gary Gensler has done a superb job at the CFTC. On October 1, swaps execution facilities-- new trading platforms to regulate the derivatives market-- opened smoothly. Gensler has BS and MBA degrees from Wharton, spent considerable time at Goldman Sachs, and has served with distinction at the U.S. Treasury Department as well as at the CFTC.

I would be interested to know about Gensler's future plans. If he desires to stay in public service, he would be an excellent pick as Fed Vice Chair. He'd also make an excellent Treasury Secretary in a future Democratic administration.

JWC--

So, would you tell this woman and mother of twin boys that she would have been better off without a gun?

http://abcnews.go.com/US/georgia-mom-hiding-kids-shoots-intruder/t/story...

Regards,

QP

"And who better to ask about women protecting themselves with guns in the face of a threat than someone who's been there?"

Jen, I agree. 100%. No one better to ask. But, curiously, you didn't ask the same question of THIS woman:

http://m.wtae.com/news/acso-homeowner-shoots-man-attempting-to-break-int...

Or any other woman who has successfully defended herself using a gun.
Wow, Rae. A plea that we not rush to judgement? I commend you!

Ok Eric, I'll bite.
Annie Oakley was an activist for women's rights. For heaven's sake, women couldn't even vote until1920, way past her heyday. But if the concepts of the glass ceiling, sexual harassment or income inequality existed during her lifetime I would bet the farm she would have front and center in the fight. One could even imagine she would have been an advocate for women's reproductive freedom.
Her legacy is not so much about guns but about a woman who used her skill to empower women to take control of their lives.
Sorry if this bursts your sepia toned bubble.
Yes. It is. Eric is "an" halibut.
